commit_message:
Flatten Aodh service configuration

This change combines the previous puppet and docker files into a single
file that performs the docker service installation and configuration.
With this patch the baremetal version of aodh services have been
removed.

Co-Authored-By: Juan Antonio Osorio Robles <jaosorior@redhat.com>
Depends-On: https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/16994/
Change-Id: I39645aff0365218d4b841ed0d9c964b3622f143a
Related-Blueprint: services-yaml-flattening

of the modules conform to the puppet standard [1].

commit_message:
Fix environments sorting

This change ensures, that custom environments (which are not included in
capabilities-map.yaml) are applied at the end of list of sorted environments
rather than just skipped

Closes-Bug: #1806406
Change-Id: Ia682284eff26883434fc516aefa8591599ec4394
(cherry picked from commit 936a599a7c6b164ea349bafbf8a198534cd65832)

subject: Release OpenStack-Ansible rocky/18.1.1
messages:
[{'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-12-11 14:13:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-12-11 17:41:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Checked on the releases-tox-list changes. Even if some commit messages look like changes to introduce new features for deployers, these are only impactful for testing/test coverage (Vagrantfile, QoS). Bash completion could be considered as the only "feature" we add, but again it's not really something for deployers (as it was never intended nor documented as such to use the utility container for such purposes.)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-12-12 10:21:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

LGTM, letting a bit of time pass to give stable team a chance to review it'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-12-12 16:43:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-12-13 00:34:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

* HPMSA-iSCSI http://os-logs.tristero.net/hpmsa-ci/97/622697/5/HPMSA-iSCSI : SUCCESS in 36:32.84'}, {'account_id': 25678, 'date': '2018-12-08 09:25:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Build succeed.

- Dell_SC_FC http://publiclogs.emc.com/622697/5/Dell_SC_FC/479 : SUCCESS in 2h 54m 46s
- Dell_SC_iSCSI http://publiclogs.emc.com/622697/5/Dell_SC_iSCSI/468 : SUCCESS in 3h 02m 41s

Leave a comment with 'run-dell-emc-sc' to trigger a recheck, for more information about CI, please see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ThirdPartySystems/Dell_EMC_SC_Series_CI"}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2018-12-11 20:11:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2018-12-11 20:40:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Sorry, but I need to question the premise that leads to this patch. That is, whether we need to distinguish between recoverable and unrecoverable driver initialization errors.

I like the blueprint goal of retrying initialization in case the previous error was recoverable. Great! But what's the downside of retrying even when the error might be unrecoverable? Sure, the error will reoccur and the log will show this happening over and over again, but is that a bad thing? If the concern is log file growth then that could be handled by the retry logic.

Also, consider that these "environment errors" might actually be recoverable. If the RBD driver fails because software modules are missing, then wouldn't it be nice to see the driver recover automatically after an admin installs the missing modules?

I see how this patch is well intended, but fear that it creates complexity that doesn't provide a clear (at least to me) benefit.'}, {'account_id': 15961, 'date': '2018-12-13 00:47:02.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Agreed on cinder meeting that driver reinitialization will be always retried. So abandon this commit.'}]

commit_message:
Add an new exception for environment error

This is the basic patch which defines a new exception
to indicate the environment error, with this error it
will not reinitialize drivers.

Change-Id: I71d4965cc9298d7500bee64dd9b5f12f2e04a2e0
Co-authored-by: Ovidiu Poncea <ovidiu.poncea@windriver.com>
Implements: blueprint driver-initialization-after-fail

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-11-12 12:22:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

Sorry that you've been waiting for a while.  We're in charm freeze, so this will be held until that goes through.  However, I noticed quite a few functions being added in percona_utils.py, but not being covered by unit tests?  I'm also wondering how we'll test this using juju bundles?"}, {'account_id': 20635, 'date': '2018-11-15 11:56:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

The referenced charm-helpers change was canceled.  Please re-link the new PR when it is available.  Thank you.'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-11-21 16:07:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-11-21 19:36:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

@Alex: The patch has been re-submitted with the missing unit tests. Sorry for that, because of the patch size I thought I share it first for a general review and I add missing tests / functionality later. With regards to functional tests I should be possible to spawn two percona clusters (pxc1 and pxc2) and relate them. Am I missing something?'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-11-23 14:47:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

(37 comments)

Firstly, thanks for doing the work to bring this feature into the charm.  I've done a fairly solid review of the code, on which I have some comments.  Note they are about making the code either more efficient, more explicit, more pythonic or just easier to read.  In a couple of places, the code doesn't appear to do what the docstring does and vice versa.  Please feel free to reach out to me on IRC if you have any questions.  Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-11-23 14:48:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

Sorry, forget the -1 on my review.'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-11-26 11:02:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

(37 comments)

Hi Alex,

I've incorporated most of your comments / changes, however, there are few I'd like to discuss further. Could you please respond to them so that I could prepare a new version of the patch?

Thanks"}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-11-26 18:25:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(12 comments)

Hi Tytus, just a few more answers to your queries. Thanks, Alex.'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-11-27 11:16:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-11-27 12:49:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(17 comments)

Alex,

Thank you very much for a quick response. I have incorporated all of your comments / suggestions now, re-run basic functionality tests on my laptop and re-submitted the patch. However, if anything requires further clarification, I am happy to go with one more round of the code review.

Regards

Tytus Kurek'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-11-27 14:46:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

Okay, I'm now +1 on this; as it's a change to percona-cluster I'd also like David Ames to have a look.  I'll let him know.  Thanks again for the changes."}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-11-27 23:48:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(10 comments)

Tytus,

Thanks for all this work. This will be a great feature.

We have just a few rough edges that need to be taken care of, most of which are in line requests.

Please also confirm only one unit from each cluster can be the master (same with slave)?
Meaning we want the IP of an individual unit rather than the VIP for the cluster?'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-11-28 22:59:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(10 comments)

Hi David,

Thank you very much for a quick review. I have already incorporated some of your suggestions on my side and will re-submit the patch once we clarify everything. There are a few points, however, which require further clarification, so let's discuss them please.

I would also like to confirm that the "master_address" attribute is going to be based on an IP address of the leader unit and not on the VIP. The reason behind it is that the leadership concept already has the "leader-settings-changed" and "leader-elected" hooks in place, so I didn't have to re-invent the wheel.

So the master - slave communication between cluster A and cluster B takes place between the leader unit in cluster A and the leader unit in cluster B. However, any change on any unit in cluster A gets propagated to all units in cluster A and cluster B. This is thanks to the mix of Percona synchronous and MySQL asynchronous replication :).'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-11-30 00:16:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(4 comments)

Tytus, thanks for getting back to me. I have tried to answer your questions in line.'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-12-03 17:50:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(4 comments)

Hi David,

I have made some changes in order to incorporate your comments / suggestions, so please have a look. If anything requires further clarification please let me know. I am submitting a new patch for a review, however, one of the unit tests is failing. If you could please help me finding out why I would be really grateful.

Thanks

Tytus Kurek'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-12-03 17:52:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-12-04 19:10:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-12-05 08:06:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-12-05 23:15:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Tytus, this is a huge improvement. We are so close.

The get_server_id needs to be unique within a given cluster. So we can't override it with cluster-id.

Regarding the validation of the input. Rather than spin here again and again. I am going to write some unit tests and some code to suggest to get my point across more clearly. But in general, I don't trust the user to get a complicated string correct on the first try. So we need to beat it to death making sure it is valid.
I'll have some code to show you soon."}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-12-06 00:11:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

This is more of what I had in mind for validation: https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/ZxjtbV6xxr/

Note that this still won't catch human error.
The follwoing is "valid" but will be wrong: 'db1;tb1:db2,tb2;db3:db4'

To fix that we would need to use json. Which is probably what I should have suggested to start. I am fine doing that as a second review.

So fix the get_server_id problem. Add some validation like what I have posted or that exactly and let's get this landed.'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-12-09 23:16:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(4 comments)

Thank you David. Re-submitting, hopefully for the last time :).'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-12-09 23:16:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-12-12 22:25:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Tytus,

We need to restore get_server_id back to master completely. Otherwise, it is ready. I have some unit_tests I'll add after this lands."}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2018-12-12 22:30:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-12-12 22:32:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2

Looks good. I'll land after a full recheck."}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-12-12 22:32:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-12-13 00:12:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
MySQL asynchronous replication

This patchset implements new relations: "master" and "slave" based
on a common "mysql-async-replication" interface which are used for
the purpose on enabling MySQL asynchronous replication between
multiple Percona XtraDB Clusters.

Change-Id: I94710bff17091516875c81ca769d8078ef5efd10
Closes-Bug: 1776171

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-12 18:55:32.000000000', 'message': 'Bring up secondary IPs on member networks

Octavia is plugging member networks, but only bringing up the first
fixed IP address on that network. This can mean that a secondary
fixed IP on the network, such as the IPv6 address is not brought
up at member creation time.

Change-Id: Ic5b19a303e53ab62875c4fc4be6ac03f926a6832
Co-Authored-By: Adam Harwell <flux.adam@gmail.com>
Story: 2004113

commit_message:
Bring up secondary IPs on member networks

Octavia is plugging member networks, but only bringing up the first
fixed IP address on that network. This can mean that a secondary
fixed IP on the network, such as the IPv6 address is not brought
up at member creation time.

Change-Id: Ic5b19a303e53ab62875c4fc4be6ac03f926a6832
Co-Authored-By: Adam Harwell <flux.adam@gmail.com>
Story: 2004113
Task: 27535
(cherry picked from commit b616cd5a33315713caf8a39c1bc86d427619e3e1)

commit_message:
Add profile tripleo::profile::base::apache_image_serve

This profile configures apache to serve container image content via
the push portion of the container registry REST API.

This will eventually replace tripleo::profile::base::docker_registry,
so they share some of the same paremeters.

Change-Id: Ib8e7fc30de323018baeb4d0550a072dd092629f2
Blueprint: podman-support

commit_message:
Deprecate crane image, add apache-image-serve

The crane component is being dropped by the Pulp project, it won't be
ported to python 3 and it has just been removed from Fedora.

This change deprecates the crane image and adds an apache-image-serve
equivalent which implements the pull registry API with only apache.

The TripleO change I48e23c8078847c9d69eeda64fad3f76f9d02dc9d for
blueprint podman-support demonstrates writing out data in the format
required for this image.

Change-Id: I7a3c7a8d5f2fd523751b659dc9933d086056d919

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-07 22:29:36.000000000', 'message': 'Remove allocations before setting vm_status to SHELVED_OFFLOADED

Tempest is intermittently failing a test which does the
following:

1. Create a server.
2. Shelve offload it.
3. Unshelve it.

Tempest waits for the server status to be SHELVED_OFFLOADED
before unshelving the server, which goes through the
scheduler to pick a compute node and claim resources on it.

When shelve offloading a server, the resource allocations
for the instance and compute node it was on are cleared, which
will also delete the internal consumer record in the placement
service.

The race is that the allocations are removed during shelve
offload *after* the server status changes to SHELVED_OFFLOADED.
This leaves a window where unshelve is going through the
scheduler and gets the existing allocations for the instance,
which are non-empty and have a consumer generation. The
claim_resources method in the scheduler then uses that
consumer generation when PUTing the allocations. That PUT
fails because in between the GET and PUT of the allocations,
placement has deleted the internal consumer record. When
PUTing the new allocations with a non-null consumer generation,
placement returns a 409 conflict error because for a new
consumer it expects the "consumer_generation" parameter to be
None.

This change handles the race by simply making sure the allocations
are deleted (along with the related consumer record in placement)
*before* the instance.vm_status is changed.

Change-Id: I2a6ccaff904c1f0759d55feeeef0ec1da32c65df
Closes-Bug: #1798688
'}]
commit_message:
Remove allocations before setting vm_status to SHELVED_OFFLOADED

Tempest is intermittently failing a test which does the
following:

1. Create a server.
2. Shelve offload it.
3. Unshelve it.

Tempest waits for the server status to be SHELVED_OFFLOADED
before unshelving the server, which goes through the
scheduler to pick a compute node and claim resources on it.

When shelve offloading a server, the resource allocations
for the instance and compute node it was on are cleared, which
will also delete the internal consumer record in the placement
service.

The race is that the allocations are removed during shelve
offload *after* the server status changes to SHELVED_OFFLOADED.
This leaves a window where unshelve is going through the
scheduler and gets the existing allocations for the instance,
which are non-empty and have a consumer generation. The
claim_resources method in the scheduler then uses that
consumer generation when PUTing the allocations. That PUT
fails because in between the GET and PUT of the allocations,
placement has deleted the internal consumer record. When
PUTing the new allocations with a non-null consumer generation,
placement returns a 409 conflict error because for a new
consumer it expects the "consumer_generation" parameter to be
None.

This change handles the race by simply making sure the allocations
are deleted (along with the related consumer record in placement)
*before* the instance.vm_status is changed.

Change-Id: I2a6ccaff904c1f0759d55feeeef0ec1da32c65df
Closes-Bug: #1798688

commit_message:
Update comment about nova-cells-v1 job

Nova is moving nova-cells-v1 to its experimental
queue set of jobs so the comment in devstack should
be updated.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/623538

Change-Id: Iefbaa9b809d1426640cbd47a42213f28c9ec5ff3
Related-Bug: #1807407

commit_message:
VMAX Ocata - a backport caused a deadlock

A backport of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/474954/2 caused a deadlock
situation of a lock within a lock when attempting to clean up and initiator
group. Ocata is the last of the SMI-S releases so the issue does not occur
in newer releases.

Change-Id: I100bde231bdbd543a3281fc8bee677b7cdec952f
Closes-Bug: #1800684

commit_message:
Elasticsearch: Define success criteria for adding snapshot repo

This adds a simple check to the Elasticsearch snapshot repo job
that will cause the job to fail if the repository isn't added
successfully

Change-Id: I9dca6ef545b43c52a37542319fa2f706b174c44b

commit_message:
Fix IPv6 in Active/Standby topology

Load balancers with IPv6 VIP addresses would fail to create due to
a duplicate address detection issue. The keepalived process would also
crash with a segfault due to a known bug[1].

This patch resolves both issues and allows load balancers with IPv6
VIP addresses to be created in active/standby topology.

[1] https://github.com/acassen/keepalived/issues/457

Story: 2003451
Task: 24657
Co-Authored-By: Michael Johnson <johnsomor@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I15a4be05740e2657f998902d468e57763c3ed52e
(cherry picked from commit fbb9397979808f36f5a26cbb04c546d27ab2342a)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-07 19:39:49.000000000', 'message': 'Drop nova-multiattach job

The dependent tempest change enables the volume multiattach
tests in the tempest-full and tempest-slow jobs, on which
nova already gates, which allows us to drop the special
nova-multiattach job which is mostly redundant test coverage
of the other tempest.api.compute.* tests, and allows us to
run one fewer job on nova/cinder/tempest changes in Stein.

The docs are updated to reflect the source of the testing
now.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/606978/

Change-Id: I744afa1df9a6ed8e0eba4310b20c33755ce1ba88
'}]
commit_message:
Drop nova-multiattach job

The dependent tempest change enables the volume multiattach
tests in the tempest-full and tempest-slow jobs, on which
nova already gates, which allows us to drop the special
nova-multiattach job which is mostly redundant test coverage
of the other tempest.api.compute.* tests, and allows us to
run one fewer job on nova/cinder/tempest changes in Stein.

The docs are updated to reflect the source of the testing
now.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/606978/

Change-Id: I744afa1df9a6ed8e0eba4310b20c33755ce1ba88

security guidelines.

A few comments inline. I can try and pull a couple of the sections of this document out into their own patches if needed.

For example, the keystone-manage limit command that checks the current limit structure against a different model certainly seems interesting. That might be a good candidate to do in another cycle though, pending what we get done this release.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-04-11 04:01:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

 > fundamentally broken.  However, the 2 level scheme is not going to
 > serve a huge class of users, and I would hate to put this out there
 > and confuse people.  Lets work on getting this right.

A question for your blog:
Where and how to save the mapping between the resource and project?  Will Keystone provide a API that when creating a VM, Nova can call it and then save the usage in Keystone, Or any other way? Can you say more here? Thanks.

BTW, I think there are mainly two purposes in this spec:
1. introduce a base usage workflow for unified limit. That is using Keystone to set the limit, using the olsol.limit to get the hierarchical limit structure and then check the usage.
2. introduce a base hierarchical limit model.

So I'd like to know what's the main problem for this spec, where can we improve or change?

At last, for the case you pointed in your blog that B2 can allocate 75 VMs though his limit is 50 VMs, I think it can't happen with the way in this spec, every time creating a VM, oslo.limit will fetch the related hierarchical limit structure with the specified project_id, and then it will ensure the new allocation will not break it. For example:
B2 has three children C21,C22,C33. B2's limit is 50. Each of His child's limit is 25. and there are 25 VMs both in C21 and C22 already. Then if creating another VM in C33, olso.limit will:
1. check the_new_VM + C33's allocation < C33's limit, pass (1+0<25)
2. check the_new_VM+C21's allocation + C22's allocation + C33's allocation < B2's limit. failed (1+25+25+0 <50). 
Does this make sense?"}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-06-05 16:38:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-06-05 17:20:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-06-05 17:31:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-06-05 17:43:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

"Where and how to save the mapping between the resource and project?  Will Keystone provide a API that when creating a VM, Nova can call it and then save the usage in Keystone, Or any other way? Can you say more here? "

No, Nova has to keep that.  Otherwise, keystone is managaing all resources everywhere, and that is too much.


The two level approach is a base case of the multi level.  It will required some aspect of the hierarchy to implement, which means there will be no real benefit to it:  once you have to maintain the hierarchy, you need to be able to query the whole hierarchy. If I move a quota from one sub project to another, Nova still needs to know that the sub-quota cannot exceed the parents quota, no matter what.  You just don't have to work up the tree.  So, you can implement the 2 level in the context of the multi level and have the same end case.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-06-05 17:49:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

> "Where and how to save the mapping between the resource and
 > project?  Will Keystone provide a API that when creating a VM, Nova
 > can call it and then save the usage in Keystone, Or any other way?
 > Can you say more here? "
 > 
 > No, Nova has to keep that.  Otherwise, keystone is managaing all
 > resources everywhere, and that is too much.
 
Right -- keystone is not going to be tracking usages of any resources. That is up to the various projects, and the current plan is that oslo.limit will be handed function objects to count usage and the various projects will provide those. Keystone will manage the *limits* and the hierarchy only.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-06-05 18:09:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)

commit_message:
Strict Two-Level Limits Enforcement Model

This spec talks about that how the hierarchical unified limits
will work in Keystone and its consumers.

In rocky, we'd like to add the strict two level enforcement model
as the base one for hierarchical unified limits.

Co-Authored-By: John Garbutt <john@johngarbutt.com>
Co-Authored-By: Lance Bragstad <lbragstad@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Morgan Fainberg <morgan.fainberg@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Ibfb2ba2ffb0115fa7cf81d30bf9a025652d9ba42
bp: strict-two-level-enforcement-model

One typo needs to be fixed.
Ignore the following if this is necessary for upgrades.
We have mixture of percona-cluster vs mysql in the config.
We seem to be hard coding 'mysql' vs charm_name(), which is fine but then we seem to be removing the group_name with 'mysql' in it.
If it is possible let's use one or the other throughout. If not let's add a few more comments to make that clear.
Alternatively, we could check for the old non-standard setup delete those resources and re-create standard ones."}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-12-06 00:17:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

[{'created': '2018-12-04 21:08:03.000000000', 'message': 'Use chelper to configure vip and dnsha settings

Use helpers from charmhelpers to generate the data to send down the
relation to the hacluster charm.

This results in a few changes in behaviour:

1) The charm will no longer specify a nic name to bind the vip. This
   is because Pacemaker VIP resources are able to automatically
   detect and configure correct iface and netmask parameters based
   on local configuration of the unit.
2) The original iface named VIP resource will be stopped and deleted
   prior to the creation of the new short hash named VIP resource.

commit_message:
Use chelper to configure vip and dnsha settings

Use helpers from charmhelpers to generate the data to send down the
relation to the hacluster charm.

This results in a few changes in behaviour:

1) The charm will no longer specify a nic name to bind the vip. This
   is because Pacemaker VIP resources are able to automatically
   detect and configure correct iface and netmask parameters based
   on local configuration of the unit.
2) The original iface named VIP resource will be stopped and deleted
   prior to the creation of the new short hash named VIP resource.

Change-Id: Id3804fb7913662b8c573f59d84e663561a687b1f

[{'created': '2018-12-04 02:33:44.000000000', 'message': 'Handle tags in _bury_in_cell0

We allowed add instance tags when booting in
Iac54b9627cb4398e45f1f15a2f4e7d6f86242093, conductor
will create tags for us in the selected cell, but
we forgot to consider the case that no valid host
was found.

So we will be unable to filter those instances in
cell0 with tags.

Change-Id: Idfe37d356b349024dfe963c934728111e1a1d314
closes-bug: #1806515

commit_message:
Handle tags in _bury_in_cell0

We allowed add instance tags when booting in
Iac54b9627cb4398e45f1f15a2f4e7d6f86242093, conductor
will create tags for us in the selected cell, but
we forgot to consider the case that no valid host
was found.

So we will be unable to filter those instances in
cell0 with tags.

Change-Id: Idfe37d356b349024dfe963c934728111e1a1d314
closes-bug: #1806515

commit_message:
Move docker network cleanup logic

Right now, both container and capsule tests are doing docker
network cleanup at the end of the tests. This commit moves
the cleanup logic to a common base class so that the code becomes
more DRY.

Change-Id: I9320f73f68b50954e57a1b9f0e3cc01c53ba102a

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-19 15:00:03.000000000', 'message': 'WIP - Add support for native TLS encryption on NBD for disk migration

The NBD protocol previously runs in clear text, offering no security
protection for the data transferred, unless it is tunnelled over some
external transport like SSH. Such tunnelling is inefficient and
inconvenient to manage. Support for TLS to the NBD clients & servers
provided by QEMU was added. This adds support to configure ndb related
qemu.conf parameters.

Since libvirt >= 4.5 is required ::nova::compute::libvirt::version
checks the OS version to map the libvirt version we can expect and
only configured the nbd parameter then.

Change-Id: Ifa5cf08d5104a62c9c094e3585de33e19e265110
Related-Bug: 1793093
'}, {'created': '2018-11-24 12:38:20.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for native TLS encryption on NBD for disk migration

Change-Id: Ifa5cf08d5104a62c9c094e3585de33e19e265110
Related-Bug: 1793093
'}, {'created': '2018-11-30 13:16:14.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for native TLS encryption on NBD for disk migration

Change-Id: Ifa5cf08d5104a62c9c094e3585de33e19e265110
Related-Bug: 1793093

commit_message:
Add support for native TLS encryption on NBD for disk migration

The NBD protocol previously runs in clear text, offering no security
protection for the data transferred, unless it is tunnelled over some
external transport like SSH. Such tunnelling is inefficient and
inconvenient to manage. Support for TLS to the NBD clients & servers
provided by QEMU was added. This adds support to configure ndb related
qemu.conf parameters.

Since libvirt >= 4.5 is required ::nova::compute::libvirt::version
checks the OS version to map the libvirt version we can expect and
only configured the nbd parameter then.

Change-Id: Ifa5cf08d5104a62c9c094e3585de33e19e265110
Related-Bug: 1793093

[{'created': '2018-10-17 23:00:43.000000000', 'message': 'Bring up secondary IPs on member networks

Octavia is plugging member networks, but only bringing up the first
fixed IP address on that network. This can mean that a secondary
fixed IP on the network, such as the IPv6 address is not brought
up at member creation time.

commit_message:
Bring up secondary IPs on member networks

Octavia is plugging member networks, but only bringing up the first
fixed IP address on that network. This can mean that a secondary
fixed IP on the network, such as the IPv6 address is not brought
up at member creation time.

Change-Id: Ic5b19a303e53ab62875c4fc4be6ac03f926a6832
Co-Authored-By: Adam Harwell <flux.adam@gmail.com>
Story: 2004113
Task: 27535

commit_message:
Add encoding to json_dump

Under python3, the default encoding is None which can lead to an error
when trying to output the results.

Change-Id: I99eb2c752898ce2946780889c3b7fe16bd2fcff1
Related-Blueprint: python3-support

commit_message:
Enable image import conversion & image output format

Glance image conversion configuration is not enabled by
puppet-glance in glance-image-import.conf.

Adding image_import_plugins & output format parameters to enable
glance image conversion.

Change-Id: I098aa0cabf2518b8861d5b58b885d9bdef54a7f6
Closes-Bug: #1807366
(cherry picked from commit 091c01b7b8698975de77ccc5b22e2581cbcf64b8)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-23 00:18:31.000000000', 'message': "Don't override sections in deep_update

When you comment all the elements in a YAML mapping, you end up with
None instead of an empty mapping, which can have bad side effect when
handling multiple environemnents. Let's handle that by ignoring the
latest None value.

Change-Id: I77ffabeb8d4cd2886ef4f41351e42ebe487b5d4b
(cherry picked from commit 2a8ce0d0656f47331a164163f9e3b302de4d3c88)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't override sections in deep_update

When you comment all the elements in a YAML mapping, you end up with
None instead of an empty mapping, which can have bad side effect when
handling multiple environemnents. Let's handle that by ignoring the
latest None value.

Change-Id: I77ffabeb8d4cd2886ef4f41351e42ebe487b5d4b
(cherry picked from commit 2a8ce0d0656f47331a164163f9e3b302de4d3c88)

commit_message:
Update registered limit policies for system admin

This change makes the policy definitions for admin registered limit
operations consistent with the other registered limit
policies. Subsequent patches will incorporate:

 - domain user test coverage
 - project user test coverage

Change-Id: If0352220670fdf5c98d0820309817416466b1466
Related-Bug: 1805372
Related-Bug: 1805880

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-27 19:33:23.000000000', 'message': 'Implement system admin role in domains API

The domains API already consumes system-scoped tokens is oslo.policy
is set to ``enforce_scope=True``. This commit introduces the system
admin role to the API, making it easier for administrators to
delegate subsets of responsibilities to the API by default.

Subsequent patches will include domain support for:

  - project readers
  - project members
  - project admins

Change-Id: Ic9a789dc3f34d9735de3b4bc4bd48b41190cbfba
Partial-Bug: 1794376

commit_message:
Implement system admin role in domains API

This commit introduces the system admin role to the API, making it
consistent with other system-admin policy definitions.

Subsequent patches will include domain support for:

  - domain user test coverage
  - project user test coverage

Change-Id: Ic9a789dc3f34d9735de3b4bc4bd48b41190cbfba
Closes-Bug: 1794376
Partial-Bug: 968696

commit_message:
Abandoned Ansible deliverables do not need relmgt

A number of Ansible deliverables are abandoned and may be
retired in the near future. As such they do not need release
management, and should be marked release-management:deprecated.

Change-Id: I0fdb2d0e54f9cb7b64145138ca8e22a147de9883

messages: [{'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-12-12 03:12:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch stable/rocky.'}, {'account_id': 6598, 'date': '2018-12-12 05:45:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14885, 'date': '2018-12-12 18:39:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-12 03:12:40.000000000', 'message': "Don't set binding:host_id before port binding

This is because the neutron DVR scheduler expects both
'binding:host_id' and 'device_owner' to be changed as an indicator
to send notification to agent to create the qrouters namespace.
Right now, kuryr changes 'binding:host_id' and 'device_owner' in
separated API requests, which confuses the DVR scheduler and
cause the missing of the notification.

Change-Id: Ifb22cc50f284dfd46eb7ba1999cd9c2c0b25a2c6
Closes-Bug: #1802163
(cherry picked from commit 7a1e1a4034cab3d36d41f7cbccf4b3da5578a528)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't set binding:host_id before port binding

This is because the neutron DVR scheduler expects both
'binding:host_id' and 'device_owner' to be changed as an indicator
to send notification to agent to create the qrouters namespace.
Right now, kuryr changes 'binding:host_id' and 'device_owner' in
separated API requests, which confuses the DVR scheduler and
cause the missing of the notification.

Change-Id: Ifb22cc50f284dfd46eb7ba1999cd9c2c0b25a2c6
Closes-Bug: #1802163
(cherry picked from commit 7a1e1a4034cab3d36d41f7cbccf4b3da5578a528)

commit_message:
Re-include octavia::db in octavia::api

The Octavia API service needs to be configured to talk to the database.
Until recently it was being configured properly via the dependency on
class octavia::controller. Commit 0ea4e10 reverted the inclusion of the
controller class but did not re-include the db class.

Change-Id: I5744ace634f9312cbedfe419f4fb878bc8052dfa
(cherry picked from commit 84a33ab65f0e6f68ff7f3f31b342b4d00e863d3e)
(cherry picked from commit a89884bc28a7bccfe22a6cb951a6f903ea4195ab)

subject: Zuul: Simplify the integrated test playbooks
messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-12-11 12:54:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2018-12-11 14:57:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-12-12 17:00:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-11 12:54:55.000000000', 'message': 'Zuul: Simplify the integrated test playbooks

When using the integrated repo for testing, only the openstack-ansible
repository can be used to kick off the tests - so if any other repo
uses it, it will always be the same path.

The existing implementation modeled from the openstack-ansible-tests
repo which implemented a job and set of playbooks which would allow
the tests to execute from any one of the other repositories - which
is not the case here.

There is therefore no reason to have this path be dynamic in any way,
so we hard code it to where we know zuul has it.

We also remove other unnecessary fact setting and ensure that bash is
used when running gate-check-commit.

Change-Id: I17780e48cac97b1f3888b8cb264c284d8ece44a1
(cherry picked from commit ab0b3abb75bdc6c4a1d86a59c08b87246cd2b025)
'}]
commit_message:
Zuul: Simplify the integrated test playbooks

When using the integrated repo for testing, only the openstack-ansible
repository can be used to kick off the tests - so if any other repo
uses it, it will always be the same path.

The existing implementation modeled from the openstack-ansible-tests
repo which implemented a job and set of playbooks which would allow
the tests to execute from any one of the other repositories - which
is not the case here.

There is therefore no reason to have this path be dynamic in any way,
so we hard code it to where we know zuul has it.

We also remove other unnecessary fact setting and ensure that bash is
used when running gate-check-commit.

Change-Id: I17780e48cac97b1f3888b8cb264c284d8ece44a1
(cherry picked from commit ab0b3abb75bdc6c4a1d86a59c08b87246cd2b025)

commit_message:
Update the min version of tox to 2.0

The verification comands used by tox need at least 2.0 version. This
patch aims to update tox version from 1.6 to 2.0 which should help with
local running of constraints targets.

Change-Id: Ie9100f138561cc3ab91caa264cc8253dca2c9c05

commit_message:
Reorder colocation creation

A colocation constraint may reference a clone resource (which
percona-cluster charm does). So, the colocation must be created
after the clones.

Closes-Bug: #1808166
Change-Id: I304df954b2f81477535fe64687af11055b932c27

[{'created': '2018-11-26 14:44:32.000000000', 'message': "Adds ability to set no-resolv for dnsmasq.

Introduces variable neutron_dnsmasq_noresolv. When it is set to true,
no-resolv option will be placed in dnsmasq-neutron.conf.

If dnsmasq_dns_servers are not set, and neutron_dnsmasq_noresolv is True
dnsmasq will reply with empty response on DNS requests,
which may be used as a workaround of
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1501206
As a con, resolver is actually won't work at all, so all networks w/o
configured DNS will stop resolving DNS.

commit_message:
Adds ability to set no-resolv for dnsmasq.

Introduces variable neutron_dnsmasq_noresolv. When it is set to true,
no-resolv option will be placed in dnsmasq-neutron.conf.

If dnsmasq_dns_servers are not set, and neutron_dnsmasq_noresolv is True
dnsmasq will reply with empty response on DNS requests,
which may be used as a workaround of
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1501206
As a con, resolver is actually won't work at all, so all networks w/o
configured DNS will stop resolving DNS.

Change-Id: I7764e0d6100a8327f84f78da64f10f8e1fa355b1

subject: Ensure that LDAP config is deployed on all keystone hosts
messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-12-11 16:21:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2018-12-11 22:14:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-12-12 16:44:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-11 16:21:50.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure that LDAP config is deployed on all keystone hosts

In I66ed21cdcf42d0c2012062c8cf74305fecbec312 the condition meant
for the setup of the domain was mistakenly applied to all tasks
including laying down the template.

This patch moves the conditional which ensures the domain is setup
on the first host to the task in question to ensure that everything
is good and well with the world again.

Change-Id: Icb7c2556306d459534e6791f16c7013d0e9fcaf5
Closes-Bug: #1804827
(cherry picked from commit 3a6a55b8d03c1668c2edee7ff5b054cbe6a9c580)

commit_message:
Ensure that LDAP config is deployed on all keystone hosts

In I66ed21cdcf42d0c2012062c8cf74305fecbec312 the condition meant
for the setup of the domain was mistakenly applied to all tasks
including laying down the template.

This patch moves the conditional which ensures the domain is setup
on the first host to the task in question to ensure that everything
is good and well with the world again.

Change-Id: Icb7c2556306d459534e6791f16c7013d0e9fcaf5
Closes-Bug: #1804827
(cherry picked from commit 3a6a55b8d03c1668c2edee7ff5b054cbe6a9c580)

messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-12-12 11:11:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-12-12 16:31:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2018-12-12 17:29:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-12 11:11:31.000000000', 'message': "prep: remove old machinectl workarounds

There are a few manual workarounds that we're placing in order
to workaround old versions of machinectl however we don't actually
leverage those and they seem to be causing a dbus restart which
causes extra problems.

This patch removes those workarounds in order to prevent restarting
dbus which causes the system to start timing out on systemd-logind.

Change-Id: I86483225754a5b1c6030ef21e2c0cdf2cd908c3b
Closes-Bug: #1807405
(cherry picked from commit f2ac4274033978f160ab9b788bf2796859f74ded)
"}]
commit_message:
prep: remove old machinectl workarounds

There are a few manual workarounds that we're placing in order
to workaround old versions of machinectl however we don't actually
leverage those and they seem to be causing a dbus restart which
causes extra problems.

This patch removes those workarounds in order to prevent restarting
dbus which causes the system to start timing out on systemd-logind.

Change-Id: I86483225754a5b1c6030ef21e2c0cdf2cd908c3b
Closes-Bug: #1807405
(cherry picked from commit f2ac4274033978f160ab9b788bf2796859f74ded)

commit_message:
Fix ansible deprecation warnings

===
[DEPRECATION WARNING]: Using tests as filters is deprecated.
Instead of using `result|search` use `result is search`. This
feature will be removed in version 2.9.
===

Change-Id: Ic2e76ece08665601476076d2f99de4c4fa2d65c4

commit_message:
Ensure that LDAP config is deployed on all keystone hosts

In I66ed21cdcf42d0c2012062c8cf74305fecbec312 the condition meant
for the setup of the domain was mistakenly applied to all tasks
including laying down the template.

This patch moves the conditional which ensures the domain is setup
on the first host to the task in question to ensure that everything

commit_message:
Ensure that systemd-resolved is present in the Centos container

For ubuntu systems this should already be installed via the 'systemd'
package, and there does not appear to be a specific package for
systemd-resolved on opensuse systems.

Change-Id: Idae9f51e2ce961ed20ee66691f044f1958ed9009

commit_message:
Update the min version of tox to 2.0

The verification comands used by tox need at least 2.0 version. This
patch aims to update tox version from 1.6 to 2.0 which should help with
local running of constraints targets.

Change-Id: I84a53543b50184b4e838cd6e597dfc80ec025588

commit_message:
Fix IPv6 in Active/Standby topology

Load balancers with IPv6 VIP addresses would fail to create due to
a duplicate address detection issue. The keepalived process would also
crash with a segfault due to a known bug[1].

This patch resolves both issues and allows load balancers with IPv6
VIP addresses to be created in active/standby topology.

[1] https://github.com/acassen/keepalived/issues/457

Story: 2003451
Task: 24657
Co-Authored-By: Michael Johnson <johnsomor@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I15a4be05740e2657f998902d468e57763c3ed52e

commit_message:
Adds ability to enable domain dropdown list on login page

Since Pike it's possible to set domains dropdown on horizon login screen
It might be usefull for private clouds, which allow users to see
full list of domains, which are present in openstack. As a pros it
simplifies login process for the customer, as they may select
corresponding domain from dropdown menu instead of regular input.
By default it is set to False, as this exposes list of domains
for unathorized users, which may not be good thing for public clouds.

Change-Id: I049489a552d99278c273feb6ae3cf5a4a7d4b8a1

[{'account_id': 29446, 'date': '2018-11-30 02:46:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-11-30 02:47:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-12-05 07:06:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for showing interest in contribution. I am adding oslo.messaging core team to review your changes and guide further.'}, {'account_id': 29446, 'date': '2018-12-05 08:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-12-07 14:20:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29446, 'date': '2018-12-08 02:23:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> (3 comments)

In the current version of neutron, user can decide the default waiting time in neutron.conf when calling an rpc service. If no response , the system will have an another try and set the waiting time twice as much as it is. It tries again and again until the waiting time reach the ceiling. However, the ceiling is just set as 10 times as waiting time, which is not only way too long for a call but not flexible as well.
What I'm going to do is add a new parameter rpc_max_timeout in neutron.conf by which users can define the ceiling of waiting time without change the default rpc_response_time.
Please see : 

 > (3 comments)

 > (3 comments)

In the current version of neutron, users can decide the waiting time (rpc_response_time) in neutron.conf when calling an rpc service. If no response, system will double the waiting time and try again until the waiting time reaches the ceiling. However, the ceiling is just set as 10 times rpc_response_time, which is not only way too long for a call but not flexible as well.

What I‚Äôm going to do is add a new parameter (rpc_max_timeout) to neutron.conf as the ceiling of waiting time, by which users can define the maximum time without modifying the rpc_response_time.

Please see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/623401/2 and https://launchpad.net/bugs/1805769 for more information. Thank you very much."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-12-10 16:10:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If this option is used for Neutron-specific logic (which appears to be the case) then it should live in Neutron. oslo.messaging shouldn't own an option that is only used in other projects."}, {'account_id': 29446, 'date': '2018-12-11 05:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 29446, 'date': '2018-12-11 06:48:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> If this option is used for Neutron-specific logic (which appears to
 > be the case) then it should live in Neutron. oslo.messaging
 > shouldn't own an option that is only used in other projects.

When calling an rpc service, it is not enough with only one configuration option rpc_response_timeout. If the server is busy, timeout secondes should be incresed to prevent the server becoming even busier. However, incresing timeout without a limitation shall not be conducted as well, otherwise there may be some calls that can never be responsed. Hence, I think rpc_max_timeout may be a good solution.
We found the problem in neutron but the issue mentioned above can happen anywhere instead of neutron only."}, {'account_id': 29446, 'date': '2018-12-11 07:21:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27954, 'date': '2018-12-11 10:37:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Nick,

I think what Doug is trying to say is that if there is not any code on oslo.messaging to handle that config option, then it probably should be declared elsewhere. So what I can see from here is either you could do the option registration in neutron itself if that is possible or propose this retry mechanism in oslo.messaging.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-12-11 14:35:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

> Hi Nick,
 > 
 > I think what Doug is trying to say is that if there is not any code
 > on oslo.messaging to handle that config option, then it probably
 > should be declared elsewhere. So what I can see from here is either
 > you could do the option registration in neutron itself if that is
 > possible or propose this retry mechanism in oslo.messaging.

Yes, that's exactly right. We want the definition of the configuration option to live in the same place as the code that uses it. So we either need the new timeout logic added to this library, or neutron should own the configuration option and put it in a neutron-specific location in the configuration file so that it's clear that the option does not apply to other services."}, {'account_id': 29446, 'date': '2018-12-12 02:49:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thank you for your suggestion. I will add this parameter in neutron."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-12-12 17:21:19.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

commit_message:
Add a configuration option

Add rpc_max_timeout option to _client_opts which can be also found in 
neutron.conf.

Rpc_max_timeout plays a role of the ceiling of the waiting time for a 
rpc call. In the current version of neutron code, seconds of waiting 
will be doubled if there is no response from the rpc server until it 
reaches the ceiling (currently it is set as 10 times 
rpc_response_timeout). 

The current ceiling is way too long for a rpc 
call and it is binded with another parameter rpc_response_timeout, making
it less flexible. What I'm going to do is add a new config parameter to
neutron.conf to let users directly define the ceiling of waiting time 
without modifying any existing parameters.

Change-Id: I816be345c90b6a4e0a501a56e672030a148041a8
Related-Bug: #1805769
Story: 2004456
Task: 28142

[{'created': '2018-12-12 03:12:30.000000000', 'message': "Don't set binding:host_id before port binding

This is because the neutron DVR scheduler expects both
'binding:host_id' and 'device_owner' to be changed as an indicator
to send notification to agent to create the qrouters namespace.
Right now, kuryr changes 'binding:host_id' and 'device_owner' in
separated API requests, which confuses the DVR scheduler and
cause the missing of the notification.

Change-Id: Ifb22cc50f284dfd46eb7ba1999cd9c2c0b25a2c6
Closes-Bug: #1802163
(cherry picked from commit 7a1e1a4034cab3d36d41f7cbccf4b3da5578a528)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't set binding:host_id before port binding

This is because the neutron DVR scheduler expects both
'binding:host_id' and 'device_owner' to be changed as an indicator
to send notification to agent to create the qrouters namespace.
Right now, kuryr changes 'binding:host_id' and 'device_owner' in
separated API requests, which confuses the DVR scheduler and
cause the missing of the notification.

Change-Id: Ifb22cc50f284dfd46eb7ba1999cd9c2c0b25a2c6
Closes-Bug: #1802163
(cherry picked from commit 7a1e1a4034cab3d36d41f7cbccf4b3da5578a528)

commit_message:
Only split url arg with memcache backend

Only split the url arg with the memcache backend, the list form breaks
the redis backend driver / library.

Change-Id: Id0e1d9351a92ba862e48f088ff15d1f77b6105d9
Closes-Bug: #1801967

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-06 16:36:48.000000000', 'message': 'Zuul: Simplify the integrated test playbooks

When using the integrated repo for testing, only the openstack-ansible
repository can be used to kick off the tests - so if any other repo
uses it, it will always be the same path.

The existing implementation modeled from the openstack-ansible-tests
repo which implemented a job and set of playbooks which would allow
the tests to execute from any one of the other repositories - which
is not the case here.

There is therefore no reason to have this path be dynamic in any way,
so we hard code it to where we know zuul has it.

We also remove other unnecessary fact setting and ensure that bash is
used when running gate-check-commit.

Change-Id: I17780e48cac97b1f3888b8cb264c284d8ece44a1

commit_message:
Zuul: Simplify the integrated test playbooks

When using the integrated repo for testing, only the openstack-ansible
repository can be used to kick off the tests - so if any other repo
uses it, it will always be the same path.

The existing implementation modeled from the openstack-ansible-tests
repo which implemented a job and set of playbooks which would allow
the tests to execute from any one of the other repositories - which
is not the case here.

There is therefore no reason to have this path be dynamic in any way,
so we hard code it to where we know zuul has it.

We also remove other unnecessary fact setting and ensure that bash is
used when running gate-check-commit.

Change-Id: I17780e48cac97b1f3888b8cb264c284d8ece44a1

[{'created': '2018-12-11 17:11:51.000000000', 'message': 'Deployed Server - get-occ-config.sh need ordered host list

Make note in documentation that it is critical to list hosts
according to node %index% number when using get-occ-config.sh
to distribute Heat agent config for pre-deployed servers.

If the nodes are not listed in the correct order the Heat
config added will/can be for a different node.

commit_message:
Deployed Server - get-occ-config.sh need ordered host list

Make note in documentation that it is critical to list hosts
according to node %index% number when using get-occ-config.sh
to distribute Heat agent config for pre-deployed servers.

If the nodes are not listed in the correct order the Heat
config added will/can be for a different node.

Related: RHBZ#1647363
Related-Bug: #1804642
Change-Id: Ie53dfae7a35b47528aa6d8eca64b1da5b1cedaf7

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-10 23:02:40.000000000', 'message': 'Allow to run docker-puppet.py with SELinux enabled

In docker-puppet.py script we try to relable
/usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules by adding ":z" suffix
in the end.

Unfortunatelly this operation is not allowed in docker with
enabled SELinux. Docker's error message is:

Error response from daemon: error setting label on mount source
'/usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules': SELinux relabeling of
/usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules is not allowed:
"Relabeling content in /usr is not allowed.".

It leads to the fact that during the configuration the jobs fails
with "Permission denied - /usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules"

There is no need to relable that folder since it's read-only.
After removing ":z" it is possible to deploy the overcloud with
enabled SELinux.

Closes-Bug: #1807680

Change-Id: I11c7c5e9594fe0cdb2a114f81033651e411c9e3c
(cherry picked from commit dcdf75b94f7a46a1095da5a9b2afc1dbcd14ac56)
'}]
commit_message:
Allow to run docker-puppet.py with SELinux enabled

In docker-puppet.py script we try to relable
/usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules by adding ":z" suffix
in the end.

Unfortunatelly this operation is not allowed in docker with
enabled SELinux. Docker's error message is:

Error response from daemon: error setting label on mount source
'/usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules': SELinux relabeling of
/usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules is not allowed:
"Relabeling content in /usr is not allowed.".

It leads to the fact that during the configuration the jobs fails
with "Permission denied - /usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules"

There is no need to relable that folder since it's read-only.
After removing ":z" it is possible to deploy the overcloud with
enabled SELinux.

Closes-Bug: #1807680

Change-Id: I11c7c5e9594fe0cdb2a114f81033651e411c9e3c
(cherry picked from commit dcdf75b94f7a46a1095da5a9b2afc1dbcd14ac56)

[{'created': '2018-11-27 16:23:07.000000000', 'message': "Create tripleo-ansible-role-job template for ansible projects.

Currently, each ansible project being used in tripleo has
defined its own jobs, or it is being using some python
related template which implies uploading the project to pypi
even though it's an ansible project.
Creating a new job template for the ansible projects allow us
defining the needed jobs to be executed for an ansible project
in a centralized way. In a first iteration only linters are
being included, as some projects do not have docs to build, but
this could be extended in the future.

Change-Id: I153b36aaa3df1821cdaa5d6590a6eaa67eeff5a1
"}]
commit_message:
Create tripleo-ansible-role-job template for ansible projects.

Currently, each ansible project being used in tripleo has
defined its own jobs, or it is being using some python
related template which implies uploading the project to pypi
even though it's an ansible project.
Creating a new job template for the ansible projects allow us
defining the needed jobs to be executed for an ansible project
in a centralized way. In a first iteration only linters are
being included, as some projects do not have docs to build, but
this could be extended in the future.

Change-Id: I153b36aaa3df1821cdaa5d6590a6eaa67eeff5a1

commit_message:
Required changes for mariadb 10.3

Mysql-python is a deprecated package and fails to build currently.
Make use of mysqlclient as is a fork of mysql-python with many bug
fixes a python3 support.
percona xtrabackup doenst work with mariadb 10.3,
replaces to use mariadb-backup tool.
https://jira.mariadb.org/browse/MDEV-15774

Change-Id: Icefe3a77fb12d57c869521000d458e3f58435374

commit_message:
Use kuryr-kubernetes-tempest-jobs project template

This commit removes the list of jobs in this plugin and instead uses
kuryr-kubernetes-tempest-jobs project-template that is defined in
openstack/kuryr-kubernetes repo. This way we'll always be in sync with
job list in that repo.

Depends-On: I34e328322538127d9c7d0b1d8f9b8edf853b8ace
Change-Id: Ia5849aad9e23be426633e217cd3484939ecd83cb

[{'created': '2018-03-22 14:20:09.000000000', 'message': "Major upgrade: stop docker container before docker rpm update

Since we use docker's --live-restore option, stopping the docker
service only stops the docker daemon and let the containers running.

If the docker package is updated during a major upgrade, we have
to stop the running containers beforehand, otherwise the updated
docker daemon might not be able to recover the state of those
containers.

Stop the containers at step 3, just before the docker package is
updated. In order to guarantee the proper sequencing of tasks,
we move the docker rpm update from the TripleoPackages service to
the Docker service.

Note that this doesn't impact pacemaker services, which are stopped
at step 2 [1].

[1]: I85e11dd93c7fd2c42e71b467f46b0044d4516524

Change-Id: I6911fd05a4c846e3d61f064394cc309c417ea8c1

Stop the containers at step 3, just before the docker package is

commit_message:
Major upgrade: stop docker container before docker rpm update

Since we use docker's --live-restore option, stopping the docker
service only stops the docker daemon and let the containers running.

If the docker package is updated during a major upgrade, we have
to stop the running containers beforehand, otherwise the updated
docker daemon might not be able to recover the state of those
containers.

Stop the containers at step 3, just before the docker package is
updated. In order to guarantee the proper sequencing of tasks,
we move the docker rpm update from the TripleoPackages service to
the Docker service.

Note that this doesn't impact pacemaker services, which are stopped
at step 2 [1].

[1]: I85e11dd93c7fd2c42e71b467f46b0044d4516524

commit_message:
Translations: Handle directories

We need to handle translations of sub-directories the same way
they are handled in our scripts to push to the translation server,
update the code.

Change-Id: I501289767d273760b0a69d52d1a9dda867fc4e04
Co-Authored-By: Ian Y. Choi <ianyrchoi@gmail.com>

Happy to see progress on this.  I do have some concerns about the current implementation though.  Details inline.'}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-08-25 01:54:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-08-25 01:55:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-08-29 22:08:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-08-29 22:13:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

I think my only remaining concern is the possible concurrent access to the socket.  If someone can convince me that it's not possible or we can prove that it's not a problem with a load test like the one Eric mentioned on the cinder review then we could maybe go with it.  I'd still be more comfortable just putting a lock around it though."}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-08-30 00:49:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-08-30 00:52:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > I think my only remaining concern is the possible concurrent access
 > to the socket.  If someone can convince me that it's not possible
 > or we can prove that it's not a problem with a load test like the
 > one Eric mentioned on the cinder review then we could maybe go with
 > it.  I'd still be more comfortable just putting a lock around it
 > though.

When will *this case* you mention happen? Based on my understanding the context will not be changed until we explicitly call sleep method or this process( I mean send back the result) finished."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-08-30 18:14:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> > (1 comment)
 > >
 > > I think my only remaining concern is the possible concurrent
 > access
 > > to the socket.  If someone can convince me that it's not possible
 > > or we can prove that it's not a problem with a load test like the
 > > one Eric mentioned on the cinder review then we could maybe go
 > with
 > > it.  I'd still be more comfortable just putting a lock around it
 > > though.
 > 
 > When will *this case* you mention happen? Based on my understanding
 > the context will not be changed until we explicitly call sleep
 > method or this process( I mean send back the result) finished.

My understanding has always been that eventlet greenthreads also yield on io operations (like reading and writing to a socket). I have to admit I'm having trouble finding an authoritative source on that though. The eventlet docs just say they "yield cooperatively" but don't go into any more detail that I can find. I do know in the past we had problems where log messages would trigger a context switch (because of file io) and it used to cause problems. That specific bug is fixed, but it shows that it is possible for a green thread to implicitly yield in the middle of its execution.

Basically I'm not confident enough in the behavior of greenthreads in this situation to be comfortable not locking a shared resource. As I said, if someone can prove that it's fine then great, but I think there are potential issues here.'}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-08-31 02:39:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> > > (1 comment)
 > > >
 > > > I think my only remaining concern is the possible concurrent
 > > access
 > > > to the socket.  If someone can convince me that it's not
 > possible
 > > > or we can prove that it's not a problem with a load test like
 > the
 > > > one Eric mentioned on the cinder review then we could maybe go
 > > with
 > > > it.  I'd still be more comfortable just putting a lock around
 > it
 > > > though.
 > >
 > > When will *this case* you mention happen? Based on my
 > understanding
 > > the context will not be changed until we explicitly call sleep
 > > method or this process( I mean send back the result) finished.
 > 
 > My understanding has always been that eventlet greenthreads also
 > yield on io operations (like reading and writing to a socket). I
 > have to admit I'm having trouble finding an authoritative source on
 > that though. The eventlet docs just say they "yield cooperatively"
 > but don't go into any more detail that I can find. I do know in the
 > past we had problems where log messages would trigger a context
 > switch (because of file io) and it used to cause problems. That
 > specific bug is fixed, but it shows that it is possible for a green
 > thread to implicitly yield in the middle of its execution.
 > 
 > Basically I'm not confident enough in the behavior of greenthreads
 > in this situation to be comfortable not locking a shared resource.
 > As I said, if someone can prove that it's fine then great, but I
 > think there are potential issues here.

There are two cases here, one the privsep created by fork and the other is via rootwrap:

for the first case, the privsep is created via fork methd, therefore , the socket would be patched, the gt itself would use GreenSocket to communicate,
because we set the block mode into none-block, there would not be any context switch [1]  [2]?
for the second case, the privsep is created via rootwrap, because we don't patch socket libaray in code, there would not any context switch during socket's send&receive method?


[1]: https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/4fd014761cde870a755472793bfe0b7aa8f73f26/eventlet/greenio/base.py#L376
[2]: https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/4fd014761cde870a755472793bfe0b7aa8f73f26/eventlet/greenio/base.py#L334'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2018-09-04 09:28:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

10^6 thanks for working on this issue.

I haven't tested the patch, but I have added some comments from a quick review of the patch.  In any case, in my opinion, this is missing appropriate tests.

We can do something like Eric suggests [1] and have some hammering tests.  Functional tests would be ideal, but even if that's not the case we could probably do it in the unit tests and we may even be able to actually confirm that the concurrency is happening.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/593561/"}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2018-09-04 09:33:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Are there any projects using privsep but not eventlets?'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-09-04 16:08:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Are there any projects using privsep but not eventlets?

I don't know for sure right now, but there are definitely projects that don't use eventlet or are looking to move off eventlet, and since we want everyone to move to privsep eventually I don't feel comfortable doing something that would exclude non-eventlet projects from using it. Besides the concurrent access to the socket thing, that's one of my major concerns with this right now. Particularly given that Cinder had to monkey-patch in its privileged code to make this work.

FWIW, I've put this topic on the Oslo PTG etherpad for some high bandwidth discussion next week. Maybe we should try to get some more users and potential users into the room for that so we get as broad input as possible?"}, {'account_id': 11279, 'date': '2018-09-13 07:17:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> concern is the possible concurrent access to the socket.

I haven't actually reviewed this change (and won't tbh), but I wanted to add:

I started off by saying "write()s to sockets with sufficient buffer space are atomic in Linux".  And then I found I was describing a long list of caveats, particularly with what eventlet might add here by monkeypatching key write() functions.

So let me say instead "we should _not_ assume writes to the socket are atomic and we should take an explicit lock in cases where there are multiple writers" ;)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-09-13 13:15:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> > concern is the possible concurrent access to the socket.
 > 
 > I haven't actually reviewed this change (and won't tbh), but I
 > wanted to add:
 > 
 > I started off by saying "write()s to sockets with sufficient buffer
 > space are atomic in Linux".  And then I found I was describing a
 > long list of caveats, particularly with what eventlet might add
 > here by monkeypatching key write() functions.
 > 
 > So let me say instead "we should _not_ assume writes to the socket
 > are atomic and we should take an explicit lock in cases where there
 > are multiple writers" ;)

Completely agree. http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/oslo.privsep/tree/oslo_privsep/comm.py#n195 appears to be locking on writes in the privileged side and http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/oslo.privsep/tree/oslo_privsep/comm.py#n158 appears to be locking on the unprivileged side, so I think we're covered?'}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-09-17 07:55:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Published edit on patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2018-09-17 11:47:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Besides the inline comment, shouldn't we have some unit tests to verify the change?"}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-09-18 08:20:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-01 20:12:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-10-11 21:55:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

A couple of concerns inline. The main things are the special casing of ping that I thought we agreed to remove, and the handling of EPIPE.'}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-10-12 02:12:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-10-12 02:13:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

I can switch this back to 10 or 5 instead of CPU count. I think for large systems this would probably still be OK since I doubt we would actually consume that many in practice, but a set lower limit does seem like a more reasonable compromise.

I'm thinking 5 would probably be sufficient. If anyone has any preferences here, just let me know and I can get this switched back to a hard coded default value.

We really want to get this in place for stein for Cinder's usage. I think it would be better to get this out there earlier in the cycle to give time to flush out issues."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-11-09 16:27:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2

Thinking more on this, I'm not sure privsep is the correct place to do rate limiting. rootwrap didn't have any form of rate limiting so it isn't a reduction in functionality for people who are migrating, and threads should be much cheaper than api processes so I'm not sure my concerns about large systems are valid here. For the most part, I think privsep should just run what it is asked to whenever possible, and if rate limiting is needed that should be done on the caller side."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-12-10 15:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

Use threads to process target function

This patch takes advantages of threads to make privsep daemon process
concurrently.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-11 16:17:42.000000000', 'message': "Force rhsm re-registration during upgrades.

The redhat-subscription ansible module doesn't cover the case
when a system is already registered via Satellite and we try to
upgrade it's repositories to a new version providing a different
activation key. The role will catch that the system is already
registered and it won't register the new activation key.
This patch passes the rhsm_force_registration option when invoking
redhat-subscription during an upgrade. This way the system will
be unregistered and registered again, activating the new key passed.

Change-Id: I9cd35882e5db47d22df8a456749188c17b48e451
Closes-Bug: #1807987
"}]
commit_message:
Force rhsm re-registration during upgrades.

The redhat-subscription ansible module doesn't cover the case
when a system is already registered via Satellite and we try to
upgrade it's repositories to a new version providing a different
activation key. The role will catch that the system is already
registered and it won't register the new activation key.
This patch passes the rhsm_force_registration option when invoking
redhat-subscription during an upgrade. This way the system will
be unregistered and registered again, activating the new key passed.

Change-Id: I9cd35882e5db47d22df8a456749188c17b48e451
Closes-Bug: #1807987

commit_message:
Handle missing or bad dmidecode

dmidecode isn't functional on all architectures.  Don't treat a missing
binary or a missing DMI table as fatal from an install POV.

Change-Id: I85f595f5fbb7fcd8c6dc589bb348e78148b80992
Related-Bug: 1790447
(cherry picked from commit f4be399e5e8d4e0e2ddf78159dd3ace61e10caca)

commit_message:
tempestmail: few updates to Storage-related notifications

- add topics to Storage-related notifications
- update the notification list for cinder: include
  another relevant test and also all the tests
  from the separate cinder tempest plugin.

Change-Id: Iddce576e2595b806310b34a135acbed25c6a05fa

commit_message:
Fix indentation in containers-prepare-parameter.yaml

This caused some of the parameters not to be taken into account by the
container prepare workflow.

Change-Id: I8e029e880b027350dd1a13baf17ad652c6230477
Closes-Bug: #1806469

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-06 22:09:24.000000000', 'message': 'WIP implement python based uploader

Some notes on the implementation:
- Copying from registry to local is done with "podman pull"
- Since podman doesn't support mirroring, images are first copied
  from the remote registry to the undercloud registry before being
  pulled
- Layers are transferred concurrently except during "podman pull"
- Local to registry push requires the unpackaged tar-split utility
  https://github.com/vbatts/tar-split which is used internally by podman
- Layers already at the destination are never copied again

TODO items for this uploader:
- unit tests
- handle manifest lists to support transfer of multi-arch images
- handle v1 manifests from quay.io
- modify the crane export change to detect a crane backed registry by
  attempting an upload then falling back to a crane export
  I4a2342c9c78e1294d20c329300a61d919ab9e0d1

Change-Id: Ie5b4e0af2134933709ae622e5e5374b72d5418a8

commit_message:
Implement python based uploader

Some notes on the implementation:
- Copying from registry to local is done with "podman pull"
- Since podman doesn't support mirroring, images are first copied
  from the remote registry to the undercloud registry before being
  pulled
- Layers are transferred concurrently except during "podman pull"
- Local to registry push requires the unpackaged tar-split utility
  https://github.com/vbatts/tar-split which is used internally by podman
- Layers already at the destination are never copied again

TODO items before this becomes the default uploader:
- package tar-split as a RDO dependency package

TODO items for later changes with this uploader:
- handle manifest lists to support transfer of multi-arch images

Blueprint: podman-support
Change-Id: Ie5b4e0af2134933709ae622e5e5374b72d5418a8

commit_message:
Accept None value for set-attribute

Allows the ``set-attribute`` introspection rule action
to use ``None`` as a valid value.

Co-Authored-By: Riccardo Pittau <elfosardo@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I1aa11c8095c4557107223e352424e3b718e2ab35
Story: #2004546
Task: #28299

commit_message:
functional: retrieve cluster to get stack_id

At the moment, if a cluster fails to be created, we fall back to
getting the node information from Heat directly.  However, this
behaviour doesn't work at the moment because `self.cluster` is
a copy of the API record on-create which does not have the stack
ID yet.

This patch makes an extra HTTP request to get the `stack_id` in
order to get the server IPs and be able to pull down the correct
information.

Story: #2002589
Task: #28341
Change-Id: I3fb3542f8ab63f38a23094d579d3df1fcb99a497

commit_message:
functional: use vexxhost-specific nodes with nested virt

This patch changes the intergration jobs to use nodes which are
at VEXXHOST that come with supported nested virtualization in
order to allow for the functional jobs to finish on-time.

Change-Id: Ie275caac1a40fb3f10a0653b66611d2ba9d1c470
Story: #2002589
Task: #28341

[{'account_id': 29470, 'date': '2018-11-26 16:45:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-11-26 16:45:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
